qas.question: In what year were hops first known to be used in beer?
What name was Adalhard the Elder also known as in 822 AD?
In which century were hops first widely cultivated for making beer?
In which century did hops become the most popular flavoring for beer?
What would you call a mixture of ingredients used for brewing before the 16th century?
What was first mentioned in 282 AD?
What did Elder the Adalhard write?
What else was Elder the Adalhard known as?
What does Heather Scottish Ales use in place of hops?
What does Lancelot Cervoise have in place of hops?

context: The first historical mention of the <b5_0>use of hops in beer<b5_0/> was from <a0_0>822 AD<a0_0/> in <b6_0>monastery rules<b6_0/> written by Adalhard the Elder, also known as <a1_0><b7_0>Adalard of Corbie<b7_0/><a1_0/>, though the date normally given for widespread cultivation of hops for use in beer is <a2_0>the thirteenth century<a2_0/>. Before the thirteenth century, and until <a3_0>the sixteenth century<a3_0/>, during which hops took over as the dominant flavouring, beer was flavoured with other plants; for instance, grains of paradise or alehoof. Combinations of various aromatic herbs, berries, and even ingredients like wormwood would be combined into a mixture known as <a4_0>gruit<a4_0/> and used as hops are now used. Some beers today, such as Fraoch' by the Scottish Heather Ales company and Cervoise Lancelot by the French Brasserie-Lancelot company, use <b8_0><b9_0>plants<b9_0/> other than hops<b8_0/> for flavouring.
